title: Multiscale Modelling of the Neuromuscular System for Closed Loop Deep Brain Stimulation

Abstract:

Title: Multiscale Modelling of the Neuromuscular System for Closed Loop Deep Brain Stimulation

The proposed project seeks to revolutionize the management of Parkinson's disease (PD) through the development and implementation of a sophisticated multiscale model for closed-loop Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS). The current standard of care for PD involves open-loop DBS, which, while beneficial, is limited by its one-size-fits-all approach, leading to suboptimal outcomes such as side-effects, limited battery life, and often significant costs. The research objectives are to improve long-term stimulation outcomes, limit side-effects, extend battery life, increase therapeutic efficacy, reduce costs, and minimize energy consumption.

To achieve these objectives, the project will develop a multiscale model capable of simulating the intricate interactions between neural sensing and stimulation, the electric field around the electrode, and the resulting effects on individual neurons, neural networks, and the generation of muscle force. The model will integrate phenomena across multiple temporal and spatial scales, offering unprecedented insights into the dynamic, nonlinear nature of the neuromuscular system in PD.

Key components of the research include conducting rigorous validation experiments to ensure the model's accuracy and using it to identify new biomarkers of neural activity. These efforts will culminate in the design of a new control strategy for closed-loop DBS systems that can dynamically adjust to the individual patient's needs. The expected outcomes include a deeper understanding of PD and the mechanisms of DBS, leading to innovative therapeutic strategies and improved patient outcomes.

The anticipated impact of this research is significant, with the potential to change the way implanted devices use electrical stimulation, ultimately enhancing the quality of life for individuals with PD. By addressing key questions that currently limit clinical implementation, this research represents a critical step forward in the field of neurotherapeutic technology.

Keywords: Parkinson's disease, deep brain stimulation, multiscale modeling, closed-loop system, neuromuscular system, patient outcomes, therapeutic efficacy.

Title: Multiscale Modelling of the Neuromuscular System for Closed Loop Deep Brain Stimulation

Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is a transformative therapy for Parkinson's disease (PD), currently operated in an open-loop system with limitations in efficacy and side effects. The proposed project aims to revolutionize DBS by developing a novel multiscale model to facilitate the transition to closed-loop DBS, which is responsive to patient-specific neural signals. This approach is designed to improve long-term stimulation outcomes, limit side effects, extend battery life, increase therapeutic efficacy, and reduce costs and energy consumption for PD patients.

The core of the research involves constructing a multiscale model that simulates neural sensing and stimulation, the electric field around the electrode, and its effects on individual neurons, neural networks, and the generation of muscle force. The model integrates data across multiple temporal and spatial scales, which allows for an advanced understanding of the neuromuscular system's dynamics. This comprehensive simulation will be rigorously validated through a series of experiments aimed at identifying new biomarkers of neural activity, which are crucial for the closed-loop system's functionality.

Expected outcomes include the design of a new control strategy for closed-loop DBS, accommodating the nonlinear nature of the system and managing both short- and long-term changes in system behavior. The resulting insights into the mechanisms of PD and DBS will lead to a paradigm shift in how implanted devices use electrical stimulation, ultimately aiming to improve patient outcomes significantly.

This research is poised to address the critical barriers to clinical implementation of closed-loop DBS by providing a deep understanding of the neuromuscular system through innovative multiscale modeling. The success of this project promises to change the landscape of PD therapy, offering a more efficient, effective, and patient-centered approach to managing this challenging condition.

Abstract:

Title: Multiscale Modeling of the Neuromuscular System for Closed-Loop Deep Brain Stimulation

Deep brain stimulation (DBS) has emerged as a transformative therapy for Parkinson's disease (PD), traditionally operated in an open-loop manner without responsive adaptation to fluctuating patient needs. The proposed project, "Multiscale Modeling of the Neuromuscular System for Closed-Loop Deep Brain Stimulation," aims to revolutionize DBS by transitioning to a closed-loop system that dynamically adjusts to real-time neural signals, potentially improving long-term efficacy, reducing side effects, and extending battery life—all of which could significantly reduce costs and energy consumption.

To achieve this, we will develop a novel multiscale model that simulates neural sensing and stimulation, captures the effects of the electric field around the electrode, models the impact on individual neurons and neural networks, and predicts the generation of muscle force. Importantly, our model will integrate data across multiple temporal and spatial scales to accurately reflect the complex dynamics of the neuromuscular system.

The research will conduct rigorous validation experiments to confirm the model's predictive power. Outcomes of this work include identifying new biomarkers of neural activity, which are critical for the real-time adjustments required in a closed-loop system. We will also design a new control strategy for DBS that caters to the nonlinear nature of the system and accounts for both short- and long-term changes in system behavior.

Anticipated impacts of this project are profound, with the potential to significantly improve patient outcomes in PD. By advancing our understanding of the disease and the mechanisms by which DBS exerts its effects, we aim to change the way implanted devices use electrical stimulation. Ultimately, this research will forge a path toward clinically viable closed-loop DBS, providing patients with a more adaptive, efficient, and personalized therapy.

Keywords: Closed-loop deep brain stimulation, Parkinson's disease, multiscale modeling, neuromuscular system, biomarkers, patient outcomes.

Abstract:

Title: Multiscale Modelling of the Neuromuscular System for Closed Loop Deep Brain Stimulation

The proposed project aims to revolutionize the treatment of Parkinson’s disease (PD) through the development and implementation of a sophisticated multiscale model for closed-loop Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS). The current open-loop DBS systems do not optimally cater to the fluctuating nature of PD symptoms and therapy needs. The objectives of this research are to improve long-term stimulation outcomes, limit side-effects, extend battery life, increase therapeutic efficacy, reduce costs, and minimize energy consumption.

The core of our research is to design a new multiscale model that will accurately simulate neural sensing and stimulation, account for the electric field around the DBS electrode, and predict the effect on individual neurons as well as neural networks. This model will also be capable of generating muscle force models, thereby providing a comprehensive tool for understanding and manipulating the neuromuscular system in PD. The integration of multiple temporal and spatial scales will allow the model to accommodate the nonlinear nature of the system and manage both short- and long-term changes in system behavior.

To validate the model, we will conduct a series of experiments to ensure its accuracy and reliability. The expected outcomes include the identification of new biomarkers of neural activity, which will enable the design of a new control strategy for closed-loop DBS, providing significant improvements in patient outcomes. The research will also offer new insights into the mechanisms of PD and DBS, ultimately leading to more effective and efficient therapeutic strategies.

This innovative approach has the potential to transform the way electrical stimulation devices are used in implanted therapies, changing the standard of care for PD patients. By developing a model that predicts and responds to patient-specific needs, our research aims to reduce the burden of PD on individuals and society as a whole.
